ygData.subject: Re: Intelligently and nonarbitrarily penalising complexity
ygData.msgSnippet: This actually happens in nature. In bacteria the DNA is replicated serially and the reproduction time is proportional to DNA length. Eukaryotes on the other

Subject: Re: Intelligently and nonarbitrarily penalising complexity
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=102323271; y=gSp1YRgA9JxC1v0RgA1FkSI1CNwJoQi59v-DqFpmEJfgiM17s8ixfQ

This actually happens in nature. In bacteria the DNA is replicated serially=
 and the reproduction time is proportional to DNA length. Eukaryotes on the=
 other hand, have a parallel DNA replication mechanism and reproduction tim=
e is independent of DNA length. This produced wildly different results in D=
NA content. Most bacteria have very lean genomes. In eukaryotes on other ha=
nd, most of the DNA holds various forms of junk. A striking example of this=
 is an amoeba having 200 times the DNA length of a human. Eukaryotes, of co=
urse, got way more sophisticated than bacteria. There are too many other va=
riables here however for us to put it down to the lack of complexity penalt=
y.
